conclusion: Objects A and B move along the same straight line from the same starting position. Their v-t (velocity vs. time) graphs are shown in the figure.
The separation Δx between the two objects at any instant equals the time–integral of their relative velocity Δx(t)=∫₀ᵗ[ v_A(τ) – v_B(τ) ] dτ.

premise: The separation Δx between the two objects at any instant equals the time–integral of their relative velocity Δx(t)=∫₀ᵗ[ v_A(τ) – v_B(τ) ] dτ.
conclusion: The separation is an extremum when the derivative d(Δx)/dt is zero: d(Δx)/dt = v_A(t) – v_B(t) = 0.

premise: The separation is an extremum when the derivative d(Δx)/dt is zero: d(Δx)/dt = v_A(t) – v_B(t) = 0.
conclusion: The two objects must have the same instantaneous velocity.
Inspecting the graph, the two curves cross only once after the start, at the instant labelled t₂.

premise: The two objects must have the same instantaneous velocity. Inspecting the graph, the two curves cross only once after the start, at the instant labelled t₂. Before t₂, v_A > v_B, so Δx is increasing. Immediately after t₂, v_A < v_B, so Δx begins to decrease.
conclusion: Therefore t₂ is the moment when Δx reaches its maximum value.
